{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3672799,"name":"","username":"Randomjohn","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/d6d6ee/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-02T20:43:55.375Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone,

Our team recently acquired a Duralast 12V 100A crank tester, and I had a few questions about how others are using this type of tool in the context of FRC.

I have read a few threads discussing load testing, but I am curious how often teams actually use this kind of tester as a quick diagnostic tool. My goal is to use it primarily for a quick **PASS/FAIL ** check to identify obviously bad batteries more quickly than with a full CBA test.

I understand that automotive batteries and FRC batteries have different characteristics and use cases, but I’d love to hear how others approach using a cranker like this. Specifically:

  • How long do you apply the load during testing?
  • Are there any key voltage thresholds you look for?
  • Do you use it regularly as part of your battery maintenance workflow?

Any tips or best practices would be appreciated. Thanks!

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-07-02T20:43:55.375Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":34,"reads":352,"readers_count":351,"score":199.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503864,"topic_slug":"using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":76350,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries/503864/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3672806,"name":"EricH","username":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-02T20:46:05.118Z","cooked":"
Randomjohn:

I understand that automotive batteries and FRC batteries have different characteristics and use cases

You mean the MOTORCYCLE battery that FRC robots use isn’t an automotive battery?

Yep, that’s right, FRC teams have been using motorcycle batteries for the last 30 years or so.

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-07-02T20:46:05.118Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":324,"readers_count":323,"score":144.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":503864,"topic_slug":"using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries","display_username":"EricH","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":4212,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"#westandwithUkraine"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries/503864/2","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3672819,"name":"","username":"Clodsire","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/clodsire/{size}/266066_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-02T20:59:30.877Z","cooked":"

OOH I know the answer to this one!

So there are two (technically three) types of lead acid batteries: starting, deep cycle, and general/dual purpose. Starting batteries are good at emitting high current over a short time, generally used for starting motors. Deep cycle batteries are good at cycling up and down and supplying a sustained power for a longer time. Dual purpose just combine the two.

FRC batteries are dual purpose. They’re good at cycling, but can also be used to start small motors. You’ll see them commonly in generators. Motorcycles generally use starting batteries.

Now as for testing batteries. You can use a CCA tester to get a generalized test of battery capacity, but it would be better to do a full discharge test. The battery is charged and discharged three times to find an overall measure of capacity. If you want to do this, take it to a batteries Plus. I can’t speak for all, but the one I worked at would test batteries for free.

TLDR: CCA will give you a rough estimate of battery capacity, but take it somewhere to be professionally tested for a more accurate result.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-07-02T21:01:19.948Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":3,"reads":291,"readers_count":290,"score":132.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":503864,"topic_slug":"using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":4212,"username":"EricH","name":"EricH","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/erich/{size}/128938_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":66542,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Some people call me the Space Cowboy"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries/503864/3","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3672825,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-02T21:08:36.281Z","cooked":"

I’ve got an old school 50A or so tester that I replaced the old clamps with an SB50 connector that I’ve used for a quick go/no-go test. Typically I expect a potentially not bad battery to be able to maintain 9+ volts or so after applying the load for around 10 seconds or so.

I know there are a lot of “or so” statements in there as I don’t expect this to be a super scientific test but want it to weed out obviously bad or low charge batteries. Testing using yours with some known good batteries will give you the stats you can apply for your tests. I don’t consider these to be traceable to any NIST standards in terms of the accuracy of the load applied or the displayed voltage on the analog dial but that’s not what I’m looking for anyway.

You’re applying 100A load so I’d adjust the time and voltage expectations but some testing will get you in the ballpark. 100A is up there so you don’t want to go too long.

Write the instructions on the case someplace so people can do this in similar ways and Bob’s yer uncle for a quick pass/fail test.

[ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries/503864/4","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3673189,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-03T14:46:38.122Z","cooked":"

The standard 100 Amp automotive tester is a useful tool, but not used super-regularly. Its #1 job is to identify that a battery has a bad cell in it. The test takes literally 10 seconds

We dig it out when we have a mysterious brownout match and suspect the battery. Tag the battery “bad/weird/dunno”, charge it back up and test. If it passes the 100 Amp tester you need to dig further into what caused your brownout… Fail the test, well, I bet you know what to do

There’s a pretty good chance that a bad-cell battery will have a similar “fail” behavior partially charged. BUT, I haven’t tried it. Maybe next time we get a failed cell I will remember… We had a rash of failed cell batteries in the Covid era. Whee. I think it was 4 or 5 of them. Honestly, at the time, it was MOST of the new batteries.

Here’s my latest version, with integrated Anderson and all the excess junk removed.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-07-03T14:46:38.122Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":157,"readers_count":156,"score":126.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":503864,"topic_slug":"using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries/503864/5","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3673417,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-03T21:43:13.093Z","cooked":"

Pandamaniacs acquired this battery tester off the recommendation of Juan Chong. (He bought a different model, but we had a Harbor Freight nearby and a coupon.)

Honestly, works a treat. We calibrated ours using some batteries us and other teams had (with known age/abuse), and it’s shockingly effective for how cheap it is.

IMG_12491920×2560 337 KB

To answer OP’s questions:

  1. We run the test until the needle has settled enough that we know the deal.
  2. Our Mendoza line is 10V under load, but I would not trust that number blindly on anyone else’s unit (even of the same make and model). Verify on some fresh and old batteries.
  3. We run it before the battery goes on the robot. One less way to get surprised during a match.

Wow! Every match, before the match???
That’s about .3 amp hours used up… I guess that’s only around 2%. Hmmmm

Of course, if it passes that test you are 100% sure its going to do a match

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":8,"updated_at":"2025-07-03T22:00:27.463Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":85,"readers_count":84,"score":21.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":503864,"topic_slug":"using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":3095,"username":"Billfred","name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/using-a-100a-crank-tester-for-frc-batteries/503864/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3673455,"name":"Billfred Leverette (he/him/not Bill)","username":"Billfred","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/billfred/{size}/225278_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-03T22:21:46.518Z","cooked":"
Weldingrod1:

That’s about .3 amp hours used up… I guess that’s only around 2%.

Not really. It’s usually on for maybe three seconds a pop before it’s super clear. So more like 0.08 amp hours.

Weldingrod1:

Of course, if it passes that test you are 100% sure its going to do a match

Exactly the point. A few seconds at 100A is well within the operating environment of a battery on FRC duty. If it can’t take this, it’s gonna be miserable on the field.
